Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-Precision U-Pb Zircon Geochronology of the Late Triassic Chinle Fluvial System of the Colorado Plateau
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: High-Precision U-Pb Zircon Geochronology of the Late Triassic Chinle Fluvial System of the Colorado Plateau

Samuel Bowring, MIT, EAR-1024196
David Fastovsky, Univ. Rhode Island, EAR-1023788

ABSTRACT
PIs propose a program of high-precision U-Pb zircon geochronology on tuffaceous rocks preserved in the Late Triassic Chinle Formation of the southwestern United States. The Chinle is a fluvial sedimentary sequence that preserves a rich fossil record that reveals the ascendancy of dinosaur faunas and the shaping of the modern biota. Reconstructing the tempo and mode of paleoenvironmental and biotic evolution recorded in the Chinle, however, has been problematic. This is largely because although a detailed lithostratigraphy and biostratigraphy have been constructed, they are not well calibrated geochronologically. High-resolution isotopic dating of key fossiliferous Chinle outcrops, such as PIs propose, would allow the wealth of information that it contains to be integrated into the global Triassic timescale. The Chinle preserves a unique record of terrestrial biotic evolution and paleoclimate in a critical time interval of Earth history. Its sequential biostratigraphic assemblages, codified as Land Vertebrate Faunachrons, are core to the understanding of the early dinosaur evolution during a period of remarkable environmental change. Proposed high-precision temporal calibration of the Chinle litho- and bio-stratigraphy will greatly enhance their utility and will allow their integration into the global late Triassic time scale. EARTHTIME standards and tracer solutions will be used facilitating comparison between labs. The work proposed is associated with a national park with the potential of exposing an estimated 500,000 visitors per year from a wide spectrum of people to the results of this study in the form of interpretive exhibits and literature. PIs are also committed to the education of Native American communities who inhabit the land which is in part the subject of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project utilized a high-precision radioisotopic dating technique, namely the uranium-lead analysis by the isotope-dilution thermal ionization mass spectrometry (U-Pb ID-TIMS), to unravel the detailed depositional history of the Upper Triassic Chinle Formation of the Colorado Plateau in the southwestern United States. The continental sedimentary strata of this formation preserve a remarkable record of fossil land vertebrates – including earliest dinosaurs and their evolutionary near-relatives – during a critical period of Earth history in terms of global climatic and environmental changes. The results of this study make possible the integration of Chinle fossil and rock records with coeval geologic formations worldwide, ultimately providing a reliable time framework for the Late Triassic biotic and climatic evolution. A reliable temporal context allows us to calibrate the Earth history and to explore cause and effect relationships among the observed tectonic, climatic and biotic changes through geologic time.

 

The primary focus of this project was the key Chinle Formation exposures in the Petrified Forest National Park in eastern Arizona, where we established a new refined time-rock framework for the Formation and its prominent record of biotic and paleoenvironmental change, spanning nearly 20 million years of Late Triassic geologic time. This work was later augmented with new geochronology from the outboard Chinle sections in northern Arizona, western New Mexico and southern Colorado, seeking to provide meaningful time correlations of rocks and fossils across the Chinle Basin superseding conventional, at time specious, rock- and fossil-based comparisons. The detailed depositional history of the Chinle depositional system can now be reconstructed with high accuracy in both time and space. A particular objective of the project was to determine the precise timing of occurrence of early dinosaurs and their closest evolutionary predecessors (collectively termed dinosauromorphs) in the Triassic of North America and its constraints on the global evolution of the early dinosaurs.

 

The crucial temporal constraints provided by this project reveal that the oldest documented record of dinosaurs in North America dates back to approximately 223 Ma (early Norian Stage of the Triassic), significantly closer in age to the archetypal primitive dinosaur assemblages of South America than previously thought. In addition, the North American record uniquely exhibits coexistence of basal dinosauromorphs, primitive saurischian dinosaurs and more advanced theropodan dinosaurs in a mixed assemblage that persisted for at least 12 million years until about 211 Ma (late Norian). These age and biogeographic characteristics are at odds with some existing hypotheses for the Triassic transcontinental radiation of early dinosaurs, particularly those models that involve delayed arrival/abundance of dinosaur in North America.

 

The project made a significant contribution to the application of high-precision U-Pb geochronology to understanding the detailed depositional history of non-marine, fluvial sedimentary systems in deep time. It highlighted the inadequacies of Triassic land fossils and lithofacies as correlation tools in reconstructing the depositional history of ancient sedimentary basins and the resulting pitfalls in deciphering the tempo of evolutionary processes on land. The results of this study contributed to a better understanding of patterns of early evolution of dinosaurs in the Late Triassic, which in turn helps to elucidate important aspects of early Mesozoic paleobiology.
